content: Yeah some people have emotional attachment to free will because they see themselves as like an empty robot without it. It may also have to do with religious beliefs.

When you try to alter part of the casual chain, that's just part of the casual chain and you've done nothing special. 

It's not really that I could see the entire casual chain, it's just that I realized it's not possible to be outside of it so free will can't be possible. It's not possible to attempt to change the decision made by the casual chain because that attempt is itself part of the casual chain. 

At the end of the process, very little actually changes. Making decisions based on preferences still feels the same. I guess the only thing that's really different is that there's no sense of "oh I should have chosen differently," because it's not possible to have actually consciously chosen differently in that moment.

I thought that Sam Harris managed to lose his sense of do-ership. 
Idk

Yes.

Experiencing a lack of do-ership is a different phenomenon from SR. A sense of shame doesn't actually require a sense of do-ership. If I am ashamed because I believe I have an unattractive face, I don't need to believe I had control over how my face ended up to feel shame about it. So long as there is an image of "me", there is still a possibility of suffering in relationship with thought. 

With that said, I think it is true that after SR, you necessarily do experience a permanent lack of do-ership. However, it definitely possible to experience a lack of do-ership without SR.

Sorry I dont think I understand your question. Before SR there were still beliefs about myself, but belief about there being a "me" who could "do things" just happened to be dropped. There were still plenty of other beliefs about a "me".
Yeah a little
Don't think so

I don't really think about it
That sort of thing has occurred to me as a thought before though. There isn't any identification with actions from the past, if that's what you're getting at.

The self-image is something that accumulates over time. After SR I stopped experiencing continuity of time through memory. Like I would still perceive motion the same way, but I stopped constructing a timeline of memories related to "me". All memories feel equally distant and unrelated to me, without any place on a timeline, because they are just thoughts occurring right now. Life becomes just experiencing the now, which is what it always is and always has been, but misunderstood. 

Instead of having knowledge about me and about the world, the division is deleted so now it all gets categorized as knowledge about the world. I think of the memories of my personal experiences as being just knowledge about past events rather than having a special relationship with "me". I still accumulate knowledge but it's no longer ever believed to be about "me". 

The process of intelligently figuring out how to arrive at a destination is more or less the exact same. My current location is just knowledge about the world not about me, the same way that the location of any other person is just knowledge about the world. A mental construct of "where the body currently is" is still used, but there is no personal identification with the construct.

Oh mb. About the first question: I don't perceive there to be a me involved in any thinking or action process at all. It's sort of just a observation of a causal chain. 

The first time I really considered determinism a few years ago, I stopped feeling like there was a "me" in control of my actions or decisions, but I still had identification with certain thoughts irrespective of having agency over things. I still believed I was something I could think about but just had no ultimately authorship over my actions. Of course that ended after SR. 

About whether SR necessarily would end the feeling of do-ership: I think the answer is yes, SR necessarily does end the feeling of do-ership. The sense of do-ership comes from identifying with a "me" who you believe has free will. The entire thing collapses when you realize you can't think about yourself.

Years before SR I lost the sense of do-ership, mostly because of mainstream arguments from people like Sam Harris and Alex O'Connor. SR has not changed that. 

I suspect that someone who did have a sense of do-ership before SR would lose it after SR, but I can't be sure. I'm even sure whether the sense of do-ership and SR are really that closely related. I'll think about it and see if I come up with anything interesting.
It sounds like the do-er does not want to do the work. Is your lack of motivation itself related to the belief you are attempting to analyze?
The inner spotlight stuff I really don't know. I feel like it doesn't really make sense. Maybe the floodlight refers to the physical sense organs, which could make the idea work.

This all hinges on how vague of a definition of meditation you can take. I define mediation as attempting to focus on the present moment. In the context of "you're always meditating", you're always perfectly focused on the present because your thoughts occur now. Once it's realized that you have no choice but to be present, you realize you have been permanently meditating and that it isn't possible to not meditate. 

I don't mean that you always have a no mind state. I don't mean that you're always perfectly calm.

Edit: to clarify, everyone is always meditating perfectly regardless of SR, since no one's thoughts can time travel
Hahahahahaha
haha
interesting, thanks for sharing
oh that makes a lot of sense

Eh not really. I noticed that after meditation there is this permeating calm feeling of presence that sticks around for a little while. But after SR, that calmness becomes permanent because you're always absolutely present. I stopped doing formal meditation because the act of meditation is not to sit with your eyes closed. It's to learn to be present, which I realized I always was. Once you realize you have no choice but to be present, the mind stops resisting it. 

I think there is still some sort of somethingness beyond presence that deeply intense meditation can offer, but that isn't something I've explored.
It's not violence, it's more like trying to gently guide a disobedient child. The mind is incredibly difficult to control. It has to settle on its own accord.

Again, want to mention that I know extremely little about meditation. Definitely not an expert. 

Meditation as a practice to build discipline and focus requires consistency for the same reason any other type of training requires consistency. I think it's possible to get benefits out of mediation without consistency, but I suspect that the effect of mediation is far stronger when it's done consistently. There is also an aspect of having to conquer some immediate desires to be able to maintain a consistent meditation routine, which can help one learn that there is no actual danger in not fulfilling an immediate desire.

I want to preface this by saying that I know extremely little about meditation. A lot of what I'm saying could just be plain wrong. 

Formal mediation what is stereotypically seen as meditation: sitting down quietly with your eyes closed and a straight back
This is in contrast with the fact that you're always meditating, which is to say that you are always completely aware of your sensory perception, so it ultimately doesn't make sense to be "cultivating awareness". However, formal mediation is still helpful in understanding what the nature of that thing you're always aware of actually is. 

My meditation routine was extremely basic. Like 15 minutes of just sitting with my legs crossed and eyes closed every night before going to sleep. I'm really not sure how much the meditation itself actually did versus the active inquiry. I suspect that the meditation itself helps with clarity of perception, like actually being able to connect the words we say to our direct sensory experience. 

As far as I know there isn't actually a way to meditate wrong. For a while it sort of feels pointless, but I don't think the effects of mediation are immediate enough to get a feeling of "I did this right" anyways.

My understanding is that the benefit from mediation is mostly in the form of feeling more grounded and mentally clear, as opposed to coming to an intellectual understanding about presence and consciousness. There's a certain clarity that really helps with understanding the context in which your thoughts occur. 

Formal mediation is an extremely powerful tool. Even starting from just minutes a day can be transformative, but it has to be consistent, not just when you feel like it. I think if you aren't going to commit to meditating you should at least have a strong understanding of why you aren't willing to do it.
Yeah that's a good way of putting it.
I disagree. I think that you could stick to meditation. Just make the reps manageable. Even 30 seconds a day can be beneficial. Mediation is like body building haha.

Could be something to look into if you're curious
There're other non SR related benefits like focus and discipline too
Do you have any meditation experience btw? I'm no meditation expert but I suspect that it can help with the "non intellectual observation" type insight
Sounds good
Nah pikachu I think you can it just won't be easy

Alr
Lmk if you have more clarifications

The word organism describes a concept. When you say "I am an organism" you believe you literally are the thing described by the idea, but not the idea itself. 

Fear as an instinctual response to a present danger is reasonable but having an emotional reaction to someone saying something is unnecessary. Ultimately your true nature is not an organism, but in the conscious experience itself. You might say that you believe the experience still ends when you die so you're still getting fucked, but why do you believe believe you need to exist in the first place? That arises from self-image. 

The concept of consciousness is the best possible abstraction of what you are, but it is still ultimately not successful because understanding the concept does not lead to an actual literal understanding of *being the consciousness*. 

I think in general your approach to self-inquiry is very intellectually oriented, which itself is fine, but ultimately the direct insight that *is* SR is not of an intellectual nature. There is a realization of a *somethingness* that is completely indescribable, which is itself consciousness. 

I bet that sounds super unsatisfying. Sorry.

@pikachu_is_boss 
Hmmm okay I'll try again. 
It is possible to think about a concept called "nothing", but while we think about "nothing" we do not actually believe we have "nothing" in our mind. However, when we think about "me" we believe that what the thought describes *actually literally is* what we are. 

I think the concept becomes more intuitive once the relationship between thought and time is understood, which is something that you have to do yourself. Is there something about the Theseus' ship analogy that doesn't make sense? That was my attempt at explaining the relationship between thought and time.

First question:
Usually when we ask a question we expect that we can think about it and then respond with words that communicate the thoughts. 
However, there are questions this method doesn't work for, because the question is unanswerable in the form of words. One such question is, "what is nothing?" Anything you respond with cannot be nothing, so it's unanswerable with words. That question of, "who am I," is the same way, since anything that you respond with communicates a thought, which is not what you are. You do not answer the question of, "who am I," by responding with more and more sophisticated words. You answer it by realizing that thoughts are not able to answer the question at all. As I understand it, the most useful thinking you can do is inquiring into the nature of thought, time, and how they relate to each other, since that explains why thoughts can't answer the question. 

Second question: 
I can't speak for others. Your understanding of the word "about" matches mine. "You can't think about yourself" means that thoughts by their very nature are not able to describe what you really are. It's just like how you can't think about nothing, since and thought *is itself* something. The reason why you can't think about yourself goes back to thought and time and their relationship. 

It's worth noting that the concept of a continuous "me" is itself the error. It's sort of like how the Theseus' ship isn't actually one ship with a continuous existence that has duration. We invent the idea of a continuous ship through thought, even though there is actually a new ship every moment which is unrelated to the ships that came before. 
Every moment there is a new "me". You exist *right now*.

SR isn't about going through each belief individually and seeing it to be false. It's a wholesale realization of an entire swath of belief to not make sense, so it's all dropped at once. 

Imagine you're back in grade school and you're doing a really long complex math problem and then get an answer that clearly makes no sense. You go back and see that at the start of your work you had "2+3=6" as an intermediate step. Once you see the error, your mind immediately sees intuitively that all the work built on top of that error is wrong too without having to go through each individual part. SR as a phenomenon works the same way. 

You could go cataloging all of your beliefs if you can find use out of it, but that isn't necessary.
Silence is an inquiry into the nature of perception and thought, whereas active questioning in an inquiry into existing belief. Both are useful tools in the context of SR.

The error is not in believing that you are something when you should instead believe something else. The error is to have any intellectual belief about yourself in the first place, because of the fundamental limitation of thought as merely being another sensory perception.
Robert Sapolsky is the goat

Self-inquiry as an activity the way you describe it is absolutely possible. SR as a phenomenon is when one realizes that all inquiry through thought into the self is completely futile, so it stops operating automatically. The end "goal" of self-inquiry is to realize it to always have been pointless in the first place, so maybe in that sense it's not possible since it can't achieve what it's "meant to" achieve. 

Trying to communicate what the "true self" is, is kind of like trying to communicate to someone who doesn't speak English what blue is. They absolutely have direct experience of what it is, but merely saying the word can't directly communicate what you mean since "the word is not the thing". The moment I say the word  "blue" what I'm talking about is an abstraction that exists in thought, as opposed to the literal direct visual perception of blue. Communicating about the "true self" is the same way, since ultimately the true self *is* the totality of present sensory perception. You have experience of it (or ig in a sense you *are* the experience of it), but no direct connection to how that word relates to your direct sensory experience.

Well now we're just getting into definitions. The purpose of mediation and self-inquiry are the same, but they are different activities. Jamie says it's possible for SR to happen without formal mediation. I think he's right, but I also think he is very careful there to say "formal" mediation, because in some sense you're always meditating because you're always absolutely aware of the entirety of your direct sensory experience. Formal mediation just cuts down on the amount of stimulus present, so it becomes easier to realize that it is impossible to not be meditating. The realization that one's "true self" is that of a pure meditative awareness as opposed to the self-image, literally is SR but phrased differently. (Talking about a "true self" can get tricky though because the moment you say it, it becomes a thought which is not what the "true self" is. This is what Jamie means by "you can't think about yourself." )

As for whether self-inquiry as you understand it to be impossible: what is your understanding of what self-inquiry is? Based on that I can try to give a better answer.

Really I have no familiarity with Gurdjieff at all, I'm just making vague intuitive guesses
I've never read this one or any of Gurdjieff's work. Is it a long read?
Hmmm I think he would ultimately claim that you're meant to go past the analogies and really experience the thing for yourself. Seems muddy though yeah.
He might just be spouting nonsense, but really I can't say.

Yeah I dunno. The G. Gurdjieff stuff seems like nonsense. The only way I can vaguely see it fit together coherently is if you take everything as being a metaphor, but at that point you can twist anything to have any meaning so why would anyone want to communicate like that. 

I know that Eckhart Tolle advocates for an extremely unorthodox interpretation of the holy Bible, essentially twisting every interpretation into an SR metaphor. I've talked to Christians about it, and they don't see the Bible like that at all. Maybe Tolle is right and all Christians are wrong? I don't know what Jesus and the other Bible writers really meant and I don't think anyone knows for sure. Maybe a lot was lost in translation. Maybe everyone misunderstood him like how (mostly) everyone misunderstood JK's teachings. Who knows.

When you talk about something it becomes a thought. When you say "the witnessing of all that happening that I call 'me'", that itself is a thought. That "me" you're trying to refer to exists in thought, not outside of it. You can't think your way out of your own thoughts, it's just not possible. 

The answer to the question is to stop trying to think your way out, and observe the observation directly without judgement. This is the original purpose of achieving a no mind state through mediation: to find the space outside of the thoughts. 

The right answer to the question "who am I" is just to remain silent, because the pure observation that is already present sufficiently answers the question.

Ah I see. 

Maybe some slight insight into philosophy and psychology regarding suffering, but that's not from the phenomenon itself, it's from the study around the concept. SR itself shouldn't have anything to do with acquiring new knowledge about something, but admittedly the version of SR that we're talking about is Jamie's SR, so maybe I learned it his way so I'll have a very similar perspective to him. 

I guess what you would be talking about is something like Ramanujan getting these insane insights into math. He never experienced SR but he did say that he got divine mathematical insight directly from God. I don't think that SR, as Jamie defines, it has anything to do with that type of stuff. Maybe all of us are too close mindedly secular to "tune into" those insights though.

Snarky answer incoming:
Why do you think you're the one telling people things? Where can you actually find yourself in that process?

Years before I discovered self-inquiry and Jamie's stuff I believed free will to be an incoherent concept, which I still believe to be the case. I got to the point where I didn't even perceive that I had free will. I believe everyone has the same degree of free will, which is none. I don't believe in personal will beyond just cause and effect. It's worth noting that there is a difference between will and emotional resistance. SR has to do with lack of emotional resistance as opposed to lack of free will. 

Not really sure. I don't really think about it much. In a sense, the whole process of all those things you described are all one giant process of everything. The nature of decisions themselves don't change from SR, but the motivations for why an option is chosen do change since the self-image is no longer affecting the decisions. My stance on free will hasn't changed from SR. If anything the previous stance has been solidified. 

I don't know about higher realms of consciousness or insights into past lives or anything like that. SR itself as a phenomenon has nothing to do with having transcendent experiences. Personally, I do suspect that all the past life and near death experiences stuff that is suggesting something beyond materialism but I don't know what it is. Really still a long shot though. I have no idea. I've never personally had those experiences, just anecdotes from other people. 

Again, not sure. There is nothing attained by SR. It's a completely subtractive phenomenon revealing the experience that was always there. I'm not sure exactly what "imperishable being" refers to either. The question of whether consciousness goes on for eternity is meaningless because all that exists is right now. From that perspective, a future death becomes meaningless, so maybe that's what it means. I don't know what happens to consciousness after death but I'm not worried about it.
